title: Intimacy Through Life Changes
description: Explore how you navigate intimacy through life's transitions and challenges.

questions.text: When major life changes happen, I expect our intimate life to...
choices: Adapt—some seasons will be different
Remain a priority even when things are hard
Need extra attention to maintain
Naturally ebb and flow

therapeutic.rationale: Expectations about intimacy through change vary. Adapters accept fluctuation; prioritizers maintain focus; attention-givers work at it; flow-accepters trust natural rhythm. Shared expectations prevent disappointment during transitions.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The prioritizer may feel the adapter is giving up; the adapter may feel the prioritizer has unrealistic expectations. Align before life changes hit.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared expectations make navigating life transitions together smoother.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you expect from your intimate life during major life changes? Is that realistic?

questions.text: During difficult seasons, what I'd need most for our intimate connection is...
choices: Grace and patience without pressure
Effort to maintain some connection
Open communication about what's happening
Reassurance that we're still okay

therapeutic.rationale: Needs during hard times vary. Grace-needers want pressure removed; effort-makers want maintained connection; communicators want processing; reassurance-seekers need relationship security. Giving the wrong thing can hurt.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different needs require different support. Ask: 'What do you need from me right now about our intimate life?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared needs during difficult times means you'll naturally support each other well.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you need for your intimate connection during life's hard seasons? Are you getting it?

questions.text: If our intimate life changed significantly due to health or circumstances, I'd want us to...
choices: Find new ways to connect and be intimate
Talk openly about what we're each feeling
Give it time while supporting each other
Seek help if we're struggling to navigate it

therapeutic.rationale: Responses to forced change vary. Adapters find alternatives; talkers process together; time-givers are patient; help-seekers use resources. Having a shared approach before crisis helps.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these approaches can work together. The key is staying connected and communicating through the change.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared adaptation approach provides a roadmap for navigating unexpected changes.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How would you handle significant changes to your intimate life? What would you need from your partner?

questions.text: My view on how intimacy should evolve over a long relationship is...
choices: It deepens and becomes more meaningful
It changes but can stay passionate
It naturally shifts in focus and frequency
It requires intentional effort to keep growing

therapeutic.rationale: Long-term intimacy views shape expectations. Deepeners see increasing meaning; passion-maintainers believe in sustained heat; shifters accept natural change; efforters believe in intentionality. These views affect how you invest.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different views may lead to different efforts. The passion-maintainer may feel the shifter is giving up; the shifter may feel the passion-maintainer has unrealistic expectations.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared long-term view aligns your expectations and efforts over time.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you hope your intimate life looks like in 10, 20, 30 years? What would make that possible?

questions.text: The conversation I'd want us to keep having about our intimate life is...
choices: What's working and what we want more of
How we're both feeling about it
How to keep growing and exploring together
That we're still attracted to each other

therapeutic.rationale: Ongoing conversation focus shapes growth. What's-working types optimize; feeling-checkers maintain emotional connection; growth-focusers expand; attraction-affirmers maintain desire. All are valuable ongoing conversations.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these conversations matter—have all of them. Prioritize whatever feels most needed right now.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared conversation focus means you'll naturally discuss the same aspects of your intimate life.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What conversation about intimacy would you like to have regularly? Are you having it?
